In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::Union{DateTime,Date}, bump::Int=+3)
    if isa(dt, DateTime)
        return DateTime(DateTime(dt) + Hour(bump))
    else
        error("Function works only for DateTime types. Please convert Date type to DateTime before using this function.")
    end
end
```
This function checks if the provided `dt` is a DateTime type or not. If it's a DateTime, it will increase the timestamp by `bump` hours (default is +3 hours) and return the new DateTime. If the input is Date, an error message is thrown indicating that this function works only for DateTime types.

Note: You may want to handle negative values of `bump` as well in case you need them. In the current implementation, a negative value of `bump` will cause an overflow and return a DateTime with an incorrect timezone.
